pr_title: Add Trace Logging of REST Requests

timeline.message:
Add Trace Logging of REST Requests

Being able to trace log all REST requests to a node would make debugging
a number of issues a lot easier.

timeline.bodyText: can you show how this will look like? In particular, what does request.getHttpChannel() print?
timeline.author: ywelsch

timeline.bodyText: Should we use the same syntax as for transport-level logging, i.e., [{}][{}] received request?
timeline.author: ywelsch

replies.bodyText: I think we can align them more closely yes if we're also going to log the response sending now. On it :)
replies.author: original-brownbear

replies.bodyText:
How about:
[2020-01-31T10:09:34,141][TRACE][o.e.h.A.tracer           ] [testTracerLog] [43072717][OPTIONS][/internal/test] received request from [Netty4HttpChannel{localAddress=/127.0.0.1:9200, remoteAddress=/127.0.0.1:39464}]
[2020-01-31T10:09:34,153][TRACE][o.e.h.A.tracer           ] [testTracerLog] [43072717] sent response to [Netty4HttpChannel{localAddress=/127.0.0.1:9200, remoteAddress=/127.0.0.1:39464}]


?
I used the hash code of the request to make a fake but good enough request id for each REST request.
replies.author: original-brownbear

timeline.message: move tracer to abstract http transport

timeline.bodyText: let's also include restResponse.status() here, as well as content type, length and X_OPAQUE_ID
timeline.author: ywelsch

replies.bodyText:
Should we move this to the finally block where we have actually sent the response?
This allows us to log something different in case where sending the response failed.
replies.author: ywelsch

timeline.bodyText: Instead of the hashCode here, I would prefer to generate an actual unique value for each request (AtomicLong generator could be in RestRequest AFAICS), and return that through a getRequestId() method.
timeline.author: ywelsch

timeline.bodyText: let's add X_OPAQUE_ID here as well (this will make for great debugging)
timeline.author: ywelsch

timeline.message: CR: trace logger in separate class
